block.p: Libya Formally Admits 1988 Jetliner Bombing Libya formally accepted responsibility for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, but in general language that lacked any expression of remorse. A letter containing Libya's admission and its pledge to compensate the survivors and renounce terrorism was presented to the Security Council president.

Libya Formally Admits 1988 Jetliner Bombing Libya formally accepted responsibility for the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103, but in general language that lacked any expression of remorse. A letter containing Libya's admission and its pledge to compensate the survivors and renounce terrorism was presented to the Security Council president.

Israel to Cede 2 Cities Israel agreed to hand over control of the cities of Jericho and Qalqilya and to allow Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian president, to leave his compound for the first time in more than a year. Israeli and Palestinian officials said the agreement gave new life to an American-led peace plan.

Liberians Reunite Monrovia Liberians poured over the bridge that had separated warring government and rebel forces, reuniting a broken city as the first relief shipments in weeks arrived by sea and air. Hundreds of rebels withdrew from the area, and as the news spread, Monrovians walked freely over the New Bridge.

Stalking a Top Terrorist Riduan Isamuddin, one of Al Qaeda's top operatives, was seized by Thai police working with C.I.A. agents after an intensive operation lasting weeks. American officials said that they believe Mr. Isamuddin could provide a wealth of information on the terror network.

Iraqi Shiites to Form Militia The most combative group of Shiite Muslims announced that they would proceed with a proposal to form their own militia to safeguard holy sites from any transgressions by American troops. The announcement came after an American helicopter forced down a flag near a mosque.

White House for Military Raises The White House said that it supported permanent increases in pay for troops serving abroad even though the Pentagon has said it prefers a more limited plan to compensate soldiers in war zones. Congress passed legislation in April for temporary increases. The Pentagon lobbied against making it permanent.

Journeyman Leads P.G.A. Another unlikely leader has emerged at a big golf championship. Shaun Micheel, left, a 34-year-old PGA Tour veteran with 163 career starts and no victories, finished the P.G.A. Championship at three under par for the tournament (137, 69-70), two strokes ahead of Mike Weir (139, 68-71) and Billy Andrade (139, 67-72), who were tied at one under par.
Ward Bennett A New York designer of furniture, houses and much more, whose clean lines and exquisite materials quietly defined an era, he was 85.
James F. Romano A longtime curator at the Brooklyn Museum of Art was 56.

An Eclectic Field of Candidates In a Mad Dash of a Recall Race The California recall election of 2003 is creaking to life with just 53 days until voters decide whether to kick Gov. Gray Davis out of office and, if so, which of the 135 accredited candidates will replace him. Among the candidates are a stripper, a former television star, a smut publisher and an aging billboard queen.

A new statewide opinion poll shows that Gov. Gray Davis of California continues to lose support in his effort to keep his job, while Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante and the actor Arnold Schwarzenegger are at the top of the list of possible successors.

The nation's governors, gathering in Indianapolis for their annual meeting, must face an awkward question lurking about, though rarely mentioned: Might California's recall election idea, like so many things from California, turn into a trend and spread to other states?

3 Deaths Point to 1 Gunman Three people have been shot to death outside convenience stores in and around West Virginia's capital in the past week, and the authorities said that a single shooter might be responsible.

Missouri Town in Disarray Citizens and officials of tiny Lake Annette, population 163 and dwindling, have been stuck in a political stalemate for the past four months. At issue is who is in charge of the town. Allies of the former mayor, Eric Atchley, have filed a lawsuit claiming election fraud and demanding a recall although Mayor George Pruitt, above, won the April 8 municipal election, 59 to 38.

Tax Evader Faces Jail Term Irwin Schiff, the nation's best-known proponent of the idea that people are not required to pay income taxes, has asked a federal district judge in Las Vegas whether a man can be held in contempt of court and jailed for selling copies of public records. The judge held a hearing on a Justice Department request that Mr. Schiff be put behind bars for contempt.

Malaria Treatment for Burundi An epidemic from late 2000 to the summer of 2001 generated 3 million cases in Burundi, a country of 6.5 million people. Increasingly, health experts are recommending a combination treatment, called artemisinin, that comes from a Chinese herb.

Ozone Seems to Be Recovering Government scientists have measured a significant drop in atmospheric levels of methyl bromide, a pesticide that is being phased out of use because it damages the planet's protective ozone layer. The scientists say the drop, 13 percent since 1998, is attributable to mandatory curbs on the chemical under the Montreal Protocol, a 1987 treaty aimed at restoring the layer.

Judge Agrees on Bail For Arms Sale Suspect A federal judge denied a request by prosecutors and ruled that a Queens man whom the authorities have linked to a plot to sell shoulder-fired missiles could be released on $10 million bail. The ruling by the judge, Joel A. Pisano of Federal District Court in Newark, allows the man, Yehuda Abraham, shown above in a courtroom drawing, to seek bail under strict conditions.

More Dead Pets Are Found The authorities in Mount Vernon, N.Y., discovered nearly 300 animals in a garage on Wednesday, dozens of them dehydrated or dead. One week ago, hundreds of animals were found abandoned in a pet shop there, left to starve and eat one another.

Suit Over Child Welfare Lawyers who sued Connecticut's child welfare agency for negligence more than a decade ago said that they were considering taking further action against it after several reports cited failures to meet court-mandated goals.

Lawsuit Over Gay School Ruben Diaz Sr., left, a New York State senator from the Bronx, has filed a lawsuit to block the expansion of a small public high school for gay students, arguing that it violates the city's antidiscrimination policies and the constitutional rights of heterosexual students.

A Study of One's Peers Sherry B. Ortner, a prominent anthropologist, is about to publish a study of her high school classmates, who graduated with her from Weequahic High School in Newark in 1958. She said she wanted to explore how her classmates were formed by the world of the 50's, with its rigid demarcations of class, gender and race.

Memoirs of Uruguay's Jews Uruguay's dwindling Jewish population has produced memoirs, academic treatises, oral histories and novels that began 20 years ago when an anthropologist began seeking letters and snapshots from immigrants.

Ruling Against Philip Morris An Illinois state judge issued an order again requiring Philip Morris USA to post a $12 billion bond within 60 days while it appeals a judgment in a smoking-related case, increasing the financial uncertainty hovering over the company.

Wall Street Back on Track Stock trading resumed about 15 hours after the lights went out, as hundreds of traders, many unwashed and most of them groggy from lack of sleep or arduous commutes, staggered to their posts at the New York Stock Exchange.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 11.13 points to 9,321.69, 130.60 points above last week's close. The Nasdaq composite index was up 1.67 points to 1,702.01, or 57.98 points higher than last week's close.
Preparedness Pays Off Many companies that made serious investments in disaster preparation came through the blackout without a bump with the help of disaster recovery companies.

New Kind of Mortgage Loan Rising mortgage rates are driving borrowers to take out loans that require them to make only interest payments for the first few years, not a worry as long as home prices keep appreciating.

Inquiry Leads to Stock Drop American Capital Strategies shares fell by 8.6 percent over two days after the Securities and Exchange Commission requested the company provide certain documents as part of an informal inquiry.
A Gain in Factory Output Companies showed the biggest gain in production in six months in July, paced by demand for cars, electronics and electricity, and consumers paid more for goods and services.
